Your underlying hypothesis appears to be this:

If class A depends on B, =
then there exist tests T(A) that test A and tests T(B) that test B such tha=
t T(A) depends on T(B).

It is on this basis that you want JUnit to manage =
those dependencies. I claim first that JUnit can't, and second that JUnit s=
houldn't.

1. JUnit can't manage the dependencies without human interventio=
n.
2. JUnit shouldn't manage the dependencies because they are not universa=
l.

I do not view dependencies the way you do. What we have in common, thou=
gh, is that we each need to be able to execute different collections of tes=
ts at different times. This is why the former is not a part of the framewor=
k and the latter is. That is the essence of framework. What you want to bui=
ld is a tool. So build it.

This mailing list has several messages showing people sc=

ite can contain any tests they want -- even if they belong to completely di=
fferent TestCase objects, and so on. They are in jail: their view is narrow=
ed artificially by not seeing the simplicity of TestSuite: it's just a coll=
ection of tests. Collect 'em however you want.
